description: Rear extension with internal reconfiguration of ground floor, internalisation of garage to create new living space.

factsheet.heading: Original House
paragraphs: Purpose built family home (likely 1960s), semi detached with integrated garage. The property boasts an interesting stepped design throughout the property with the floors zig-zagging up the property. The garage, located at lower ground floor, and the kitchen/dining space at upper ground floor were outdated and under utilised.

factsheet.heading: Proposed Works
paragraphs: Our clients were looking to maximise the available space within the property by converting the existing garage into a habitable space and extending to the rear. The new combined lower ground/upper ground floor space was then to be used for a more generous family dining/kitchen space, and a new family living area.

factsheet.heading: Key Brief Goals
paragraphs: The property benefits from its proximity to a row of tall trees sited just to the rear of the garden, outside of the property boundary. We wanted to maximise the connection from inside to outside, brining in the views of these trees as well as lots of light. The spaces within needed to reflect this connection with a spacious, and connected layout.

factsheet.heading: Materiality
paragraphs: The original property was built from standard brickwork. We wanted to ensure the new extension connected with the host building, but also to stand proudly as a contemporary addition. We chose a hand thrown brick with varying tonal finishes in the beige/white/grey range, and couple this with a soft-pink zinc roof and drainage finish.

Internally, we exposed the brick wall to the garage, and applied a painted finish whilst exposing the new brick work within the extension. The floors are micro cement. The joinery within the space is a combination of white oak and plywood; all finished with a soft white wash.
